text: hello all. I was having a nerdy content discussion today, and a CEO of a new startup in my network mentioned that he thinks that the white paper/long-form gated content is dead. He said ‘nobody downloads these any more’. I still see value in them as a concept — but am I just a fuddy duddy? Would love to hear your thoughts, whether pro/con  — and what your approach is :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: hello all. I was having a nerdy content discussion today, and a CEO of a new startup in my network mentioned that he thinks that the white paper/long-form gated content is dead. He said ‘nobody downloads these any more’. I still see value in them as a concept — but am I just a fuddy duddy? Would love to hear your thoughts, whether pro/con  — and what your approach is

text: I don't think it's so black-and-white. Gating has obvious downsides (SEO, reading accessibility esp for mobile of PDFs, the UX of the actual gate) but also huge upsides for email capture, which is why so many of us do it, I imagine. It also depends on your audience and what kind of content they consume and how they want to consume it. If you big rock/small rock the content you can have the best of both worlds and get some data to back up either side on which gets most engagement & helps drives results.

elements.text: I don't think it's so black-and-white. If you big rock/small rock the content you can have the best of both worlds and get some data to back up either side on which gets most engagement & helps drives results.

text: big rock/small rock? I’m not familiar with that expression.

elements.text: big rock/small rock? I’m not familiar with that expression.

text:
<@U0231C2LYNM> I’m pro it, but it very much depends on 1) your niche, 2) your market, 3) your audience.

If folks are cool with gated content, go for it. (e.g., b2b spaces). If folks are anti gated content, nix it (e.g., more b2c spaces).

It’s something that’s worth testing.

Network CEO _may_ be saying that because their gated content isn’t performing - which doesn’t say a lot about the strategy, just their implementation.

elements.text:

text: <@UUJBM2PJ7> yeah — I’m a huge fan of making content accessible too :slightly_smiling_face: I love what I’ve seen vaguely termed as the ‘light paper’ — a really highly visual on-page experience.

elements.text: yeah — I’m a huge fan of making content accessible too
I love what I’ve seen vaguely termed as the ‘light paper’ — a really highly visual on-page experience.

text:
<@U0136JJHUSK> Are you thinking more professional learning - for which I'd second lattice - or school/K-12, higher ed? And what's your definition of stand out content? I hear good stuff about 360learning but unfortunately the website wont work for me / my plugins so that rules it out.

I work in the UK schools edtech sector and I have to say that our audience of headteachers, teachers, tend to respond pretty well to just pedagogically sound content that they know will either show them some new way of teaching that they can learn from or alternatively, provides them with something they can use in their classroom and will suit their students' needs. I'd say it's a relatively unsophisticated market for content marketing. One of the big UK edtech successes is <http://twinkl.co.uk|twinkl.co.uk> who have made a fortune from downloadable worksheet pdfs. Teachers love them.

text:
<@U01KH3P18RZ> I’ve never used the term, but I think ‘big rock/small rock’ refers to:
• Big rock: The big cornerstone piece of content
• Small rock(s): blog posts/videos/webinars etc on a chapter/data point to extend its ROI

text:
Hi all,
What are your go-to resources for learning to build and optimize inbound funnels?

Blogs, webinars, courses--anything that helped you up your game for yourself or clients?

elements.text:
Hi all,
What are your go-to resources for learning to build and optimize inbound funnels?

Blogs, webinars, courses--anything that helped you up your game for yourself or clients?

text:
You’ll want to read this book: <https://www.amazon.com/90-Minute-Building-Marketing-Funnels-Convert/dp/B088L911Q8>

Buddy of mine (founder of <http://SegMetrics.com|SegMetrics.com>, Keith Perhac) wrote it.

It’s the real deal, exceptional, and actionable.

> *Finally*, a top-down guide that walks you through every step of setting up and optimizing your automated marketing funnels.

Buddy of mine (founder of
SegMetrics.com

, Keith Perhac) wrote it.

It’s the real deal, exceptional, and actionable.
Finally
, a top-down guide that walks you through every step of setting up and optimizing your automated marketing funnels.

text: Keith (author) worked with course creators (including Ramit Sethi of I Will Teach) on their blog/webinar/course funnels. He knows his stuff and the book is a treasure.

text: Not to be flippant, but I'd ask for the data to support that and, absent any, would just ignore the hot take.  (I talk to a _lot_ of early stage CEOs, BTW, and "nobody downloads those anymore" sounds suspiciously like "I don't download those, and therefore I presume nobody does," though YMMV)

text: (Not that I'm suggesting being needlessly confrontational with a friend, BTW, but more like, I'd say "oh, is that a gut take, or have you seen data that backs that?")

text:
I agree with everyone else. This sounds like a personal hunch. I've seen others say it's all about the value the reader believes they'll gain vs. what they have to give up. I'm happy to give up my name/email for an in-depth study I can't get elsewhere. If it just seems like a bunch of concatenated blog posts, I'm less interested.

That hunch sounds similar to someone who recently told me we should remove forms from the top of our landing pages because "they were too spammy". But those forms increased our conversion rate.

text: Is it dead? No. But the perceived value of a gated asset is much harder to earn. 5-10 years ago, you could publish a gated guide and people would download it because it was the only one in existence for your target audience/industry. Fast forward to today and your gated guide is one of hundreds being published by competitors and brands that aren’t even remotely comparable to yours.

elements.text: Is it dead? No. But the perceived value of a gated asset is much harder to earn. 5-10 years ago, you could publish a gated guide and people would download it because it was the only one in existence for your target audience/industry. Fast forward to today and your gated guide is one of hundreds being published by competitors and brands that aren’t even remotely comparable to yours.

text: Came here to say what Ronnie said, so to piggyback off that: it really comes down to what you're gating. I think there's a lot of truth to the idea that people today are protective of their inboxes and picky about what they opt in for as a result. And at the same time, as Ronnie pointed out, there market is more flooded with gated stuff than ever before. So you have to make sure that the value of what you're offering in a gated asset is substantial enough to overcome those initial objections of "Ugh, another gated asset" and "Do i really want my inbox cluttered up by these people?"

text: Not to toot my own horn, but our content team at Panorama Education (K-12 edtech) is doing some stand-out work with content for K-12 district and school administrators across our blog, gated content/toolkits, video, and more. Happy to select/share a few examples of content resources we've produced if you're interested!

text: Gating isn’t perfect, but it’s brought us some $100k+ leads. Thanks to careful targeting, our MQL > SQL ratio is ~.9. Lots of value in that!
